Tel.: +86 22 23507730; fax: +86 22 23507730. Graphical abstract Ordered mesoporous silicas with structures of MCM-41, MCM-48 and SBA-15 were synthesized. Oxidative desulfurization activities of dibenzothiophene and 4,6-dimethyl dibenzothiophene on the mesoporous silicas were investigated using tert-butyl hydroperoxide as an oxidant. Textures and surface properties of the synthesized mesoporous silicas were studied by X-ray diffraction, N2-sorption, FT-IR and NH3-temeprature programmed desorption. The results show that oxidative desulfurization catalytic activities increase with surface area and surface acidity of the mesoporous silicas. Oxidative desulfurization mechanism on MCM-41 was investigated by the addition of surface silanol inhibitor such as acetic acid, water and triethylolamine or silylation of surface silanol groups using trimethylchlorosilane. A hypothetical mechanism based on surface silanol-mediated oxidation desulfurization is proposed. Oxidative desulfurization activities for Mo catalysts supported on MCM-41 were also investigated to identify the difference in oxidative desulfurization mechanism between MoO3 catalysts and pure mesoporous silicas. Keywords Mesoporous silica Oxidative desulfurization Mechanism Surface silanol-mediated 1 Introduction Sulfur in transportation fuels is a major source of air pollution. Ultra-deep desulfurization of fuels attracted many attentions not only because of increasing environmental concern and legal requirements on a sulfur content, but also because of the application of ultra-low-sulfur fuels for fuel cell [1–3]. For example, the very stringent environmental regulations have limited the level of sulfur in diesel to less than 15ppm since 2006 in the United States, less than 10ppm since 2005 in Europe, and less than 50ppm since 2008 in China. In addition, liquid hydrocarbons are considered a potential fuel for automotive and portable fuel cells due to their higher energy density and readily existing infrastructure for production, delivery and storage [2]. However, trace amounts of organic sulfur presented in liquid fuels, particularly gasoline and diesel, are sufficient to considerably poison the noble metal catalysts used in reforming and transforming process of fuels and the electrode catalysts used in fuel cell stacks, then reduce the activity and lifetime of the catalysts [4]. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is highly efficient for removal of thiols, sulfides, and disulfides. However, it is difficult to reduce refractory sulfur compounds such as dibenzothiophene (DBT) and its alky-substituted derivatives especially 4,6-dimethydibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) to an ultra low level using only conventional HDS [5,6] due to their alky chain steric hindrance. Severe operating conditions with high temperatures, high pressures, and high hydrogen consumption are required for HDS to achieve ultra-deep desulfurization of diesel with S concentration <10ppm. High capital and operating costs are inevitable. Therefore, it is necessary to develop alternative ultra-deep desulfurization processes of adsorption [7], extraction [8], oxidation [9] and bioprocesses [10]. Among these, oxidative desulfurization (ODS) combined with extraction or adsorption is considered to be one of the most promising processes. Much interest has been shown over the last decade for the application of ODS to liquid fuels [11–15]. During oxidative desulfurization, sulfur-containing organic compounds can be oxidized by the electrophilic addition of oxygen atoms with the sulfur atoms to form sulfoxides and sulfones. The chemical and physical properties of sulfoxides and sulfones are significantly different from those of hydrocarbons in fuel oil, and consequently they can be removed by distillation, solvent extraction, or adsorption. The refractory-substituted DBTs are easily oxidized under mild reaction conditions (atmospheric pressure and relatively low temperature) without use of expensive hydrogen, therefore, the capital requirement for an ODS unit is significantly less than that for a deep HDS unit. Otsuki et al. [16] investigated the relationship between electron densities of the sulfur atoms and oxidative reactivities of the sulfur-containing compounds using hydrogen peroxide and formic acid as oxidants for ODS. The results indicate ODS activities for DBTs increase with an increase in the electron densities of the sulfur atoms in sulfur compounds. It is suggested that in ODS reaction 4,6-DMDBT can be more easily oxidized than DBT due to its higher electron density. ODS is confirmed to be a potential route for desulfurization of sterically hindered sulfides such as 4,6-DMDBT. In our previous study [17], using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oil-soluble oxidant, the oxidative reaction mechanism and the reactivities of the sulfur compounds (DBTs) in the presence of various catalysts were investigated with a flow reactor. It is found that MoO3/Al2O3 exhibits the highest ODS activity for DBT among the catalysts examined. The ODS mechanism on MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst is inferred that the coordination of hydroperoxide to MoO is prompted by the polarization of Moδ+ Oδ− bond when MoO3 is dispersed on Al2O3. Via the formation of a five-member ring, the electrophilicity of peroxy oxygen is prompted, and therefore high oxidative activity can be obtained. Further, the oxidation reactor was combined with an adsorption reactor disposed in line and a continuous oxidation/adsorption process was developed [18]. The oxidation of undesirable sulfur compounds presented in a desulfurized light gas oil (LGO; sulfur content: 39ppm) was performed with TBHP as the oxidant on 16wt.% MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst. The total sulfur content can be decreased to the value less than 5ppm, which is under the most drastic future restrictions imposed by environmental laws. Chica et al. [19] synthesized well-designed titanium containing MCM-41 mesoporous materials, which successfully reduced sulfur content in a simulated diesel from 200ppm to 0ppm by ODS using TBHP as the oxidant. Stranger and Angelici [20] reported that using silica gel as an ODS catalyst, sulfur concentrations in simulated petroleum solutions containing 374ppm sulfur of DBT or 4,6-DMDBT could be reduced to 1ppm within 40min at 90°C using TBHP. In addition, Kropp et al. [21] have studied the mechanisms of surface-mediated reaction on silica gel and alumina in the oxidation of various sulfur containing organic compounds using TBHP. Above all these reports, there is no research focused on the ODS reactivity and the mechanisms catalyzed over pure mesoporous silicas with various structures which presented ordered structures and large surface areas compared with silica gel. In this paper, we synthesized mesoporous silicas with structures of MCM-41, MCM-48 and SBA-15 aiming to acquire pure mesoporous silica materials with different structures and surface properties. The de-template procedures were carried out with calcination or extraction. The ODS activities were investigated in both batch reactor and fix-bed reactor using TBHP as an oxidant. The ODS active sites on pure mesoporous silicas were studied by introducing protic solvent in the ODS reaction or silylation of the surface silanol groups before reaction. According to the results, the ODS mechanisms on pure mesoporous silicas are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials MCM-41 and MCM-48 samples were synthesized as reported elsewhere [22–24]. Typically tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was slowly added to a stirred solution of NaOH and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTABr) at 303K. The molar compositions of gel for MCM-41 and MCM-48 are TEOS/NH3·H2O/CTABr/H2O=1/8/0.13/60 and TEOS/Na2O/CTABr/H2O=1/0.25/0.65/62, respectively. After being stirred for 3h, the gel was crystallized at 393K for 48h in stainless reactors with Teflon liners. In case of molybdenum containing sample, a certain amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was added in the solution. SBA-15 samples were synthesized according to the method of reference [25]. Typically 8.5g TEOS was added to a stirred solution of 120g 2M HCl and 4.0g P123 at 308K. After stirring for 24h, the gel was crystallized at 363K for 12h in a stainless reactor with Teflon liner. All the synthesized samples were washed with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried at 313K under vacuum condition. The MCM-41 containing molybdenum was calcined in air under 823K for 5h (MoM41C) [26]. Each one of pure silica samples was divided into two parts for calcination (marked with suffix C) and extraction (marked with suffix E). The first part was calcined at 623K in air for 5h (SiM41C, SiM48C and SiS15C). The second part of MCM-41 and MCM-48 (2.0g) was extracted in a mixed solution of ethanol/concentrated hydrochloric acid (75ml, v/v: 8/1) using a round-bottom flask equipped with a condenser pipe at 363K for 8h, then filtered, washed with ethanol/acetone and vacuum dried at 333K for 4h (SiM41E and SiM48E) [27,28]. In case of SBA-15 sample, 2.0g powder was soaked in 20g 15% H2O2 solution in a stainless reactor with Teflon liner, hydrolyzed at 398K for 24h, then washed with deionized water and ethanol, dried at 333K for 4h under vacuum condition (SiS15E). 6% Mo/M41C and 16% Mo/Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized as follows: 0.08g or 0.21g (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was dissolved in 10g deionized water, then 1.0g SiM41C or Al2O3 supports were impregnated in this aqueous solution with stirring, dried at 393K for 4h, then calcined in air flow at 823K for 4h. 2.2 Desulfurization of DBT as model sulfur compound Oxidative desulfurization of DBT was carried out in both glass batch reactor and fixed-bed reactor. The simulated diesel oils used in this work are MD500 (500ppm DBT), MD800 (500ppm DBT and 300ppm 4,6-DMDBT) and MD5000 (5000ppm DBT). Typically, the simulated diesel MD 500 was prepared as follows: 0.5g DBT was dissolved in 99.5g decalin to obtain 5000ppm DBT solution. 0.752g 65%TBHP was dissolved in 99.3g decalin to obtain about 5000ppm TBHP solution. Due to the molar mass of DBT is about 2 times of TBHP, so equal amount of DBT solution and TBHP solution was weighed just before ODS reaction, then 10 times diluted with decalin to obtain MD 500 with TBHP/DBT (O/S) molar ratio of 2. A typical ODS process in a batch reactor is as follows: in a 50ml round bottom flask, simulated diesel (MD500 or MD800) was heated to a desired temperature with stirring, then 0.1g catalyst was added, the oxidation reaction last for about 3h. Oxidative desulfurization was also carried out in a stainless steel fix-bed reactor (i.d. 3mm). 0.10g catalyst was loaded in the reactor and heated at 353K. Then the feed (MD5000) was introduced by a peristaltic pump at atmospheric pressure with WHSV of 40h−1. The outflow was analyzed per half hour by GC-FID. 2.3 Analysis Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on Rigaku D MAX using CuKα radiation (40kv, 100mA), from 0.6 to 20° (2θ) with a scanning rate of 1°/min. Small angle X-ray scattering of SBA-15 sample was measured on Bruker AXS Nano-Star with scanning range of 0–3°. N2 adsorption–desorption analysis was carried out at 77K on a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 apparatus. FT-IR spectra were recorded on KBr pellets by a BRUKER VECTOR 22 spectrometer in the region of 400–4000cm−1. Oxidation products were analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC-FID), which was equipped with a SGE AC10 capillary column, 0.25mm in diameter and 30m in length. The products were identified by checking the retention time with standard materials. Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) experiments were performed in a U-shaped tubular quartz reactor. Prior to the experiments, the catalysts were pretreated at 500°C for 10min in 5vol% O2/Ar mixed gas, and then cooled to 50°C in N2. The catalysts were purged by 500ppm NH3/N2 for 40min or until the outlet NH3 concentration was stable. The catalysts were purged with N2 to remove any weakly absorbed NH3 at 50°C. When NH3 concentration was lower than 15ppm, the catalysts were heated from 50 to 850°C at a ramping rate of 10°C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of synthesized mesoporous silicas Small-angle powder XRD patterns of the synthesized mesoporous silicas prepared by calcination and extraction are shown in Fig. 1 . For both SiM41E and SiM41C samples, an intense diffraction peak (100) together with an additional peak (110) and a very weak peak (200), characteristic of hexagonal ordered MCM-41 structure [29], are obviously observed in XRD patterns of the prepared materials. It can be observed that SiM41E shows stronger diffraction intensity of main peaks than SiM41C, which can be attributed to partial collapse of mesoporous structure for the calcined SiM41C sample. Both SiM48E and SiM48C samples show a high intensity (211) peak followed by a smaller (200) one in the 2θ range of 2–3°, whereas several other peaks are observed in the 3–6° range, which corresponds to the Ia3d cubic symmetry reported for MCM-48 type molecular sieves [30–32]. Similarly, partial collapse of the mesoporous structure can be observed for the calcined SiM48C sample. As shown in Fig. 1, XRD patterns for both SiS15E and SiS15C samples show typical highly ordered SBA15 mesoporous structures. Each pattern shows three peaks corresponding to (100), (110) and (200) reflections of the 2-D hexagonal space group (p6mm) [33]. Different from SiM41 and SiM48 samples, XRD peak intensity of the extracted SiS15E sample is lower than that of the calcined SiS15C sample. It means that the mesoporous structure of the extracted SiS15E sample is partly distorted or collapsed. SiM41E and SiM48E samples are extracted with a mixed solution of ethanol and hydrochloric acid by refluxing to eliminate the same template CTABr, but in case of SiS15E sample, the powder is hydrolyzed in H2O2 solution in autoclave at 120°C to eliminate the template P123. It is inferred that oxidative decomposition of the template P123 using H2O2 during the extraction procedure may lead to the collapse of the mesoporous structure for the extracted SiS15E sample [34]. Some structure parameters of synthesized mesoporous silicas are summarized in Table 1 . Compared with SiM41 and SiM48 samples, SiS15 samples present larger interplanar distance and pore size, and therefore higher thickness of wall, which means SiS15 samples present higher hydrothermal or solvothermal stability [25]. For all samples, the calcined ones show lower surface area and pore volume compared with extracted ones, which can be explained by partial sintering of the surface of mesoporous structure after calcination. The surface areas for these synthesized mesoporous silicas decrease in the order of SiM48E>SiM48C>SiM41E>SiM41C>SiS15E>SiS15C. The molecular diameter of DBT is much smaller than the pore diameter of mesopore. Therefore, the synthesized mesoporous silicas are inferred to be promising for oxidation of DBT. 3.2 Oxidative desulfurization on SiM41C catalyst Pure mesoporous silica SiM41C was investigated as an ODS catalyst in a batch reactor and exhibited considerablely high ODS activity for DBT and 4,6-DMDBT at 353K as shown in Fig. 2 . Here DBTs conversion means the ratio of reacted sulfur (DBTs) concentration to initial sulfur (DBTs) concentration. Elimination of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT will not occur with the absence of TBHP despite the existence of the catalyst, indicating that nearly no adsorptive desulfurization occurred under the reaction conditions. Further, oxidation of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT using TBHP will not occur without the catalyst as shown in Fig. 2. SiM41C can effectively decrease sulfur content of MD 800 at 353K. 4,6-DMDBT, which is considered to be a representative refractory organosulfur compound for HDS, is observed to be more easily eliminated than DBT using this catalytic ODS reaction. In order to examine the kinetics of the oxidative reaction, the oxidative reaction of model sulfur compounds was also carried out at 313 and 333K on SiM41C under the same reaction conditions. The results in Fig. 2 show that a linear relationship of ln(S/S 0) versus reaction time is obtained for each sulfur compound (DBT and 4.6-DMDBT) at 353K. Here S/S0 means unreacted sulfur (DBTs) concentration/initial sulfur (DBTs) concentration in a batch reactor. Similarly, the linear relationships are also obtained at 313 and 333K for each sulfur compound. The results suggest that the oxidative reaction of each sulfur compound can be treated as a pseudo first-order reaction. Therefore, the following equation applies: ln(S/S 0)=−k ODS t, where k ODS = A exp(−E/RT), A is the pre-exponential factor, E is the apparent activation energy, R and T are the gas constant and reaction temperature, respectively. The reaction rate constants (k ODS) at various temperatures can be obtained from the slopes for the sulfur compounds. The obtained results are shown in Table 2 . As reported by Otsuki et al. [16], the divalent sulfur of DBT can be oxidized by the electrophilic addition reaction of oxygen atoms to the hexavalent sulfur of DBT sulfone, the reactivity of oxidation becomes higher for a sulfur atom with higher electron density. The trend of the reaction rate with the structure is in terms of (a) reductive ability of the lone pair electrons on sulfur atoms and (b) steric strain in the reaction products, sulfoxides and sulfones. The sulfur atoms of 2,5-DMT (dimethyl thiophene), 2-MT (methyl thiophene) and thiophene have electron densities of 5.716, 5.706 and 5.596, respectively. These low electron densities are not sufficient to be oxidized by hydrogen peroxide and formic acid as reported by Otsuki [16]. Nevertheless, BT, of which the electron density is 5.739, and other model compounds such as 4,6-DMDBT, 4-MDBT and DBT with higher electron densities of 5.760, 5.759 and 5.758, can be oxidized to form corresponding sulfones. The apparent rate constants decreased in the order: 4,6-DMDBT>4-MDBT>DBT>BT. This result indicates that rate constant increases with the increase in electron density, which is to say that more effective electron congregated on the sulfur atom can lead to faster oxidation. 4,6-DMDBT has two alkyl substitutional groups, which can provide more effective electron from adjacent site to the sulfur atom. Thus oxidation of 4,6-DMDBT is faster than DBT and other sulfur containing compounds such as benzothiophene, thiophenes and thiols. These special aspects make ODS a very potential process compared with conventional HDS. Fig. 3 shows the Arrhenius plots of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT on SiM41C catalyst according to k ODS at different temperatures. The apparent activation energies of oxidative reaction are obtained from the slopes of Arrhenius plots. The results show that E are almost the same: 42±2kJ/mol for DBT and 4,6-DMDBT on SiM41C catalyst. This result suggests that there are essentially no differences in the mechanism of oxidative reaction for DBT and 4,6-DMDBT catalyzed by SiM41C catalyst. On the other hand, the activation energy of oxidative reaction is much lower than that of HDS, as reported to be 84±2kJ/mol [35]. Oxidative reaction occurred more easily at much lower reaction temperature compared with HDS. It is clear that the mechanism of oxidative reaction is very different from that of HDS. The effect of reaction temperature was carried out in a batch reactor under given conditions. As shown in Fig. 4 , DBT conversions at three reaction times (5min, 15min, 60min) during ODS reaction are chosen to make results more clear. Corresponding TOF values are calculated from mole of converted DBT per mole of silanol on the surface of the mesoporous silicas per second. According to SiO bond length and bond angle [36], the surface area of each Si with associated oxygen atom is calculated to be 0.13nm2, which is equivalent to silanol density of 7.7OHnm−2 [37]. The theoretical mole of surface silanol (mmolg−1) of each mesoporous silica can be calculated from surface area (m2 g−1)×7.7 (nm−2)/6.02×1023 (mol−1) and the results are shown in Table 3 . Temperature can severely accelerate the oxidative reaction. Higher temperature not only made the oxidative reaction faster, but also promoted desorption of DBTO2 from the active sites of the catalyst. DBTO2 is the final product of oxidation which has higher polarity than DBT and is considered to be easily adsorbed on the catalytic active sites. At lower temperature, DBTO2 can be strongly adsorbed on the surface of SiM41C and relevant detected GC peak in the liquid product is weak, preventing further adsorption of DBT to be oxidized and resulting in low conversion of DBT. DBTO2 adsorption on SiM41C can be verified by the fact that a large amount of DBTO2 was detected by GC when the catalyst was flowed with ethanol after ODS reaction. TOF value decreased with reaction time at each reaction temperature, while increased with increasing temperature at each reaction time. Above the reaction temperature of 373K, little increase in TOF value was observed. This may be attributed to the low thermostability of TBHP at higher temperature (TBHP will lost its oxygen at 368–373K). The optimal temperature of ODS should be 353K under the current reaction conditions. The oxidative reaction of DBT with various O/S molar ratios at 353K was also investigated. The O/S molar ratio was defined as the molar ratio of the amount of oxidation agent (TBHP) to the amount of sulfur compounds (DBTs). 2mol of TBHP are required stoichiometrically for the oxidation of 1mol of DBTs to corresponding sulfones. As shown in Fig. 5 , at the first 3min of the ODS reaction, an obvious increase in TOF value with increasing O/S ratio was observed. While almost the same TOF values were obtained at 15min or 60min for various O/S ratios. The results suggest that with enough reaction time such as 15min in a batch reactor, O/S ratio above stoichiometrical 2:1 shows little effect on ODS activity. 3.3 Oxidative desulfurization on various mesoporous silicas Traditionally mesoporous silicas are fine supports for various catalysts, due to their extremely large surface area, fast diffusion of molecules in the mesoporous enabling good conversions. Due to that silica gel presented a certain ODS activity as reported, three series of pure mesoporous silica with structure of MCM-41, MCM-48 and SBA-15 were synthesized to investigate the ODS activity on high surface area maintained pure silica. The summarized ODS activities are shown in Fig. 6 . All mesoporous silicas showed high DBT conversion, which decreased in the order of SiM48E> SiM48C>SiM41E>SiM41C>SiS15E>SiS15C, while their surface areas decreased in the same order. It is supposed that surface area could be important for mesoporous silica catalyzed ODS reaction. On the other hand, TOF values at each reaction time are almost the same for SiM41 and SiM48 series, indicating the same ODS activity on the same amount of active sites. In case of SiS15 series, lower TOF values are obtained, which may be due to the collapse of the mesoporous structure. The amount of calculated surface silanols and reaction rate constants (k ODS) on various synthesized mesoporous silicas at 353K are shown in Table 3. Linear relationship between k ODS and the theoretical amount of surface silnaol was obtained for various mesoporous silicas as shown in Fig. 7 . An increase in the surface area means an increase in the amount of surface silanol groups as calculated above. In addition, k ODS on silica gels with surface areas of 340 and 650m2/g are also shown in Table 3. Lower ODS activities are obtained for silica gels with lower surface areas compared with mesoporous silicas. The large amount of surface silanol groups existing on mesoporous silicas may act as active sites for ODS reaction, which becomes an important factor for ODS activity. Kropp et al. [21] has confirmed the surface of silica consisted of silanol groups that fell into two classes. The majority of the groups had a distance of approximately 500pm, well beyond the limit for internal hydrogen bonding, were isolated silanol groups. When the silica was equilibrated at about 120°C, approximately 15% of the silanol site was germinal and hence sufficiently close to form hydrogen-bonded chains through interaction with adjacent OH groups. When the temperature was above 200°C, dehydration would occur between adjacent silanol groups and form oxygen-bridge bond. Therefore, calcination at high temperature could result in loss of surface silanol groups and contraction of mesoporous structure as well as distort the structure to some extent, while de-template by extraction method can avoid high temperature and preserve the original surface status as synthesized. Each of the extracted samples shows higher ODS activity than the corresponding calcined sample as shown in Fig. 8 , which can be attributed to larger amount of surface silanol groups existed on extracted samples. Surface silanol groups may act as a mediate between the TBHP molecular and DBT/4,6-DMDBT molecular. SiM48E was the most effective catalyst, which had the largest surface area, and more surface silanol groups. It is also supposed that the unique Ia3d structure of MCM-48 may level up the activity to some extent for its better capability of material transportation. The IR-spectra of the calcined samples SiM48C, SiM41C and SiS15C are given in Fig. 8. The samples were calcined at 500°C for 4h before IR test to eliminate physical adsorbed H2O. The IR spectra of extracted samples are not shown here due to that their physical adsorbed H2O overlapped surface silanol adsorption bands. The narrow adsorption band in the range of 3745–3750cm−1, corresponding to the isolated OH groups [38], is weakly observed in all samples. On the other hand, an adsorption in the range of 3200–3700cm−1, responsible for the silanol groups participating in hydrogen bonding [39,40], is obviously observed for calcined mesoporous silicas. The results show that the isolated silanol groups almost disappeared and hydrogen-bonded silanol groups mainly existed on the synthesized mesoporous silicas. NH3-TPD is frequently used to determine the number and strength of the acid sites in catalysts. The NH3-TPD profiles of calcined mesoporous silicas of SiM48C, SiM41C, SiS15C are shown in Fig. 9 . The catalysts were pretreated at 500°C and the extracted samples were not tested here. There are two distinct regions at 100–200°C and 330–800°C for calcined samples respectively. For the mesoprous silicas the peak at lower temperature is related to weak acid sites. The peak at higher temperature above 330°C is assigned to strong acid sites [41,42]. The surface acidity of synthesized silicas can mainly be attributed to the surface silanol groups [21]. As reported by Sindorf and Maciel [43], the hydrogen-bonded silanol groups are more acidic (pK a 5–7) than isolated silanol groups (pK a 9.5). TPD peak at higher temperature (330–800°C) is attributed to strong acidic sites related to hydrogen-bonded silanol groups. The total amount of the strong acidic sites (330–800°C) decreases in the order of SiM48C>SiM41C>SiS15C, which means a decrease in the number of silanol groups on the surface of mesoporous silicas. This order is consistent with the order of surface area and ODS activity. The silanol groups on the surface of mesoporous silicas are suggested as the active sites for ODS reaction. 3.4 Mechanism of surface silanol-mediated oxidation The oxidation of DBT actually contains two steps: firstly, DBT was oxidized into sulfoxide, which was the reaction determined step (R.D.S.), and then further oxidized to sulfone. In our study, no sulfoxide was detected by GC analysis under any reaction conditions. Therefore, the rate-determination step is the oxidation of sulfide to sulfoxide, and sulfoxide formation is considered to dominate the reaction rate. According to the suggestions that surface silanol groups of silica samples performed as the catalytic active sites in oxidative desulfurization, a hypothesized reaction mechanism was brought forward here based on the mechanism reported by Kropp et al. [21] Scheme 1 illustrates the complete ODS mechanism of DBT on mesoporous silicas, which can be described preciously as follows: 1. tert-butyl hydroperoxide was adsorbed on the surface of mesoporous silicas by coordination with surface silanol. A five-member ring was formed via reciprocal hydrogen bonding, in which both the silanol group and the hydroperoxide serve as a hydrogen bond donor and acceptor. The electronic density of peroxy oxygen is lowered and therefore the electrophilicity of peroxy oxygen is prompted. 2. When the sulfur atom of dibenzothiphene nucleophilic attacked the specific oxygen atom in the five-member ring (electrophilic oxidation), two protons shifted and the transfer of the oxygen atom to dibenzothiphene molecule occurred. Dibenzothiphene sulfoxide is formed and this step is the rate-determination step. 3. The formed sulfoxide adsorbs at the active sites of silanol groups by hydrogen bond, the electronic density of sulfur atom in sulfoxide is lowered, apparently activated for nucleophilic attack by the oxygen atom of unbound tert-butyl hydroperoxide. Hence, there is a reversal in mechanism from electrophilic oxidation to nucleophilic oxidation when sulfoxide is oxidized to sulfone, which step reacts faster than the rate-determination step (sulfide→sulfoxide). 4. The final product sulfone adsorbs on the active sites of silanol groups leading to the hindrance of the oxidative desulfurization reaction on mesoporous silica. Sulfone can be easily flowed down by methanol or ethanol after ODS reaction for the regeneration of catalyst. The molecular of THBP formed a five member ring with the silanol group, thus the amount and activity of surface silanol group is the critical factors. This process happened on surface silanol, which served as a surface mediate. Thus it can be inferred that silanol inhibitor or partial silylation of silanol groups can lead to the loss of ODS activity. A series of experiments has been carried out to verify this mechanism. Fig. 10 shows the effects of surface silanol inhibitor (protic solvent) such as acetic acid (HAc), water (H2O) and triethylolamine (TEA) on the ODS reaction, which can form strong hydrogen bond and can be competitively adsorbed on the surface silanol of SiM41C. As shown in Fig. 10, one equivalent amount of HAc and H2O showed inhibition effects on ODS reaction. When the addition amount was 10 times of the amount of DBT, the ODS activities were more severely inhibited. TOF value decreased with the amount of HAc and H2O. In case of TEA, only one equivalent amount could greatly inhibit the ODS reaction. TOF value decreased significantly with the addition of TEA. This is because TEA is a strong silanol group inhibitor. Once TEA competitively adsorbed on the surface silanol groups of SiM41C, TBHP became hardly to form hydrogen bond with surface silanol. Partial silylation of the surface silanol groups on SiM41C using timethylchlorosilane (TMCS) was also carried out and the results were shown in Fig. 11 . 1.0g SiM41C was suspended in anhydrous toluene, then a certain amount of TMCS was added under stirring, and refluxed for 4h. The solid powder was filtered, washed with toluene, ethanol and acetone, and then dried at 40°C under vacuum condition. Obviously the more usage of TMCS, the lower activity and TOF value on SiM41C exhibited. It suggests that partial silylation of the surface silanol groups on SiM41C will reduce the amount of the surface silanol groups, and then lead to the inhibition effect on the ODS activity. These experimental results suggest that the inhibition of silanol groups can lead to the inhibition of ODS activities, and can directly be the proofs for the surface silanol-mediated oxidation of DBT in Scheme 1. According to the above suggestions, the life time test was performed using a flow fixed-bed reactor consequentially. In our previous study [17], we have reported that using TBHP as an oxidant 16% MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst presented the highest ODS activity among the catalysts examined (CrO3/Al2O3, WO3/Al2O3, V2O5/Al2O3, etc.). A peroxidic oxidation mechanism of DBT on MoO3 with TBHP was proposed as shown in Scheme 2 . The crystal structure of MoO3 shows MoO6 distorted octahedra with MoO bond length of 1.67, 1.73, 1.94, 1.94, 2.25, 2.33Å [44]. The appropriate distance between Mo atom and oxygen atom of MoO3 is 1.94Å, and the distance between oxygen atom and hydrogen atom of TBHP is 1.93Å. A five-member ring is considered to be easily formed with the coordination of hydroperoxide to MoO, which is prompted by the polarization of Moδ+ Oδ− bond when MoO3 is dispersed on Al2O3, and therefore, the electrophilicity of peroxy oxygen is prompted. The sulfur atom of DBT nucleophilic attacked the specific oxygen atom (electrophilic oxidation), two proton shifted and the transfer of the oxygen atom to DBT molecule occurred. DBT sulfoxide and tert-buthanol are formed. In order to investigate the difference in the ODS mechanism on MoO3 catalyst and pure mesoporous silicas, life time tests of ODS reaction in a continuous fix-bed reactor were carried out on SiM41C, Mo/M41C (6% MoO3 supported on SiM41C), MoM41C (6% MoO3 structured in SiM41C) and 16% MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts [45]. The reactant is 5000ppm DBT in decalin (ten times the concentration in a batch reactor) to make the catalysts deactivate faster. The results were shown in Fig. 12 . The ODS activity of each sample continuously declined during 8 hours’ test. All Mo catalysts show higher initial ODS activities than pure mesoporous silica. The high initial ODS activities for Mo/M41C and MoM41C catalysts can be explained by the fact that both Mo and surface silanol act as active sites. Moreover, Mo active sites show higher activity than surface silanol active sites. MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst shows the highest initial ODS activity and the most rapid deactivation rate, indicating that Mo and surface silanol groups functioned differently when they act as active sites. Although Mo/M41C and MoM41C exhibited higher initial ODS activity than SiM41C, but deactivated more promptly. This could be the reason for strong adsorption of the oxidative product DBTO2 on Mo active sites or incorporated in the framework of SiM41C. Fig. 13 shows IR-spectra for catalysts after 8 hours’ ODS reaction in a fixed-bed reactor. In IR spectrum using DBTO2 as a standard compound [46,11], the absorption peaks are stretching vibration of SO bonds at 1289 and 1166cm−1, SO2 scissoring vibration appearing in the 500–600cm−1 range. It is clear that Mo/SiM41C and MoM41C adsorbed much more DBTO2 than SiM41C after the same ODS reaction procedure. MoO bond is suggested to show higher polarity on Al2O3-supported Mo catalysts than OH bond on mesoporous silicas. Therefore, stronger adsorption of DBTO2 on Mo catalysts occurs and higher deactivation rate is observed for Mo catalysts. The highly polar oxidative product DBTO2 acted as the hindrance of further DBT conversion due to that DBTO2 accumulated on the surface of Mo catalysts by coordination with MoO bond or surface silanol. Then the amount of catalytic active sites became less along with the reaction time of ODS. As shown in Schemes 1 and 2, a similar five-member ring intermediate was formed during the oxidative reaction on both SiM41C and Mo/Al2O3 catalyst. The difference in ODS mechanism between surface silanol on SiM41C and MoO bond on Mo/Al2O3 catalyst is the bond length and polarity of the active sites. The bond length of MoO and silanol OH is 1.94Å and 0.96Å, separately. Therefore, MoO bond is considered to form five-member ring more easily than OH bond with the coordination of hydroperoxide in TBHP. Moreover, MoO bond is suggested to show higher polarity than surface silanol OH bond, leading to higher ability of lowering the electronic density of peroxy oxygen in the five-member ring, and therefore a higher ODS activity. On the other hand, higher adsorption ability of product DBTO2 on the Mo active sites due to higher polarity of MoO bond, which is confirmed by IR spectra in Fig. 13, will lead to a harder hindrance of ODS reaction than that happened on surface silanol active sites. Deactivated catalysts after 8 hours’ test could be easily regenerated by flowing with methanol or ethanol in the fix-bed reactor in situ (at 50°C with WHSV of 100h−1), DBTO2 was washed off from the deactivated catalyst. Large quantity of DBTO2 can be detected by GC in the liquid after washing. Most of the catalysts can recover their 90% of original activity after regeneration. As discussed above, the same activation energies of oxidative reaction are obtained for DBT and 4,6-DMDBT, which means no essential difference in the ODS mechanism of DBTs. Sulfoxide formation is the rate-determination step in ODS reaction. In this step electrophilic oxidation occurred and sulfur atom nucleophilic attacked peroxy oxygen atom. With lower electronic density of peroxy oxygen atom, easier electrophilic oxidation will occur. This can be verified by the fact that Mo/SiM41C shows higher ODS activity than pure SiM41C. Similarly, with higher electronic density of sulfur atom, easier nucleophilic attacking will occur. The electronic density of sulfur atom in 4,6-DMDBT is higher than that in DBT. Therefore, higher ODS activity is obtained for 4,6-DMDBT than DBT. 4 Conclusions According to all results obtained above, the surface silanol groups on the mesoporous silicas would act as the oxidative desulfurization active sites. The results obtained above can be summarized as follows: 1. 4,6-DMDBT can be more easily oxidized than DBT using TBHP as oxidant on SiM41C catalyst. The activation energies are almost the same: 42±2kJ/mol for DBT and 4,6-DMDBT on SiM41C catalyst. 2. With enough reaction time such as 15min in a batch reactor, O/S ratio above stoichiometrical 2:1 showed little effect on ODS activity. 3. Linear relationship between ODS activity and the amount of surface silnaol was obtained for various mesoporous silicas. According to NH3-TPD and IR results, the increase in the surface area presents the increase in the amount of surface silanol groups. 4. The addition of surface silanol inhibitor (protic solvent) and silylation of surface silanol could severely inhibit the ODS reaction on SiM41C catalysts. 5. The high initial ODS activities for Mo/M41C and MoM41C catalysts can be explained by the fact that both Mo and surface silanol act as active sites. Moreover, Mo active sites show higher activity than surface silanol active sites. coredata.dc:description: Ordered mesoporous silicas with structures of MCM-41, MCM-48 and SBA-15 were synthesized. Oxidative desulfurization activities of dibenzothiophene and 4,6-dimethyl dibenzothiophene on the mesoporous silicas were investigated using tert-butyl hydroperoxide as an oxidant. Textures and surface properties of the synthesized mesoporous silicas were studied by X-ray diffraction, N2-sorption, FT-IR and NH3-temeprature programmed desorption. The results show that oxidative desulfurization catalytic activities increase with surface area and surface acidity of the mesoporous silicas. Oxidative desulfurization mechanism on MCM-41 was investigated by the addition of surface silanol inhibitor such as acetic acid, water and triethylolamine or silylation of surface silanol groups using trimethylchlorosilane. A hypothetical mechanism based on surface silanol-mediated oxidation desulfurization is proposed. Oxidative desulfurization activities for Mo catalysts supported on MCM-41 were also investigated to identify the difference in oxidative desulfurization mechanism between MoO3 catalysts and pure mesoporous silicas.
